results.notes:
According to what I believe to be the current understanding, the aborted fruit bodies seen here represent a species of Armillaria. But, according to C du Q, analysis has revealed the presence of hyphae of both Armillaria and Entoloma abortivum in these aborted forms. Thus, it appears that either of the proposed IDs applies here.

Found not far from normal Armillaria fruit bodies; no E. abortivum fruit bodies observed in this spot.

results.notes:
2020-09-27 – Adair County, KY – Photo by Linda Waggener, ColumbiaMagazine.com
Earl Coffey placed his hand on the giant mushroom he discovered on the family farm to help demonstrate its extraordinary size. After 24 hours away from its roots the mushroom was turning dark in color as mushrooms do, and becoming quite odiferous. Neighbor Gary Darling said he’d once tried to eat a bit of this type wild white mushroom and it had been followed by worrisome stomach troubles so he recommended observation only. Joe Coffey took exacting tools and documented the mushroom’s measurements for the record – it’s 62 inches around/circumference, 7.5 inches tall and 16.5 inches across/width.
results.location_name: Earth

results.notes: These have been a common find over the past week and all of the pictures were taken in the past four days (25th-29th). All were found growing in sandy soil near pine oak mixed woods. Most were found in the grassy area along the tree line. It is a solid mushroom with bright yellow pores and a bright yellow & red stipe and a dark reddish cap. It all bruises a dark blue immediately after being bruised. The cap, stipe pore surface and also bruises dark blue when cut open from top to bottom and then it resolves to a dark slate gray color after a few minutes. The small fruit bodies to the largest all have the same pore color and appear stuffed or has really small pore openings.

results.notes: A somewhat common find on the gulf coast. I typically find them in the cooler months of the bolete season. This summer I did manage to find a few in July after some tropical storms dumped significant rain in this area. The pink scabers are distinct and the cap color does vary a bit from a dark brown to a light tan. I do find these out in grassy areas away from the tree line but i also find them near oak and sometimes pine as well.

A single mature fruitbody growing from under well-decayed log in mixed deciduous woods with oak and beech.
Overall height = 12 cm; cap footprint = 9.5 cm; cap flesh = 1 cm thick above stipe; stipe = 11 cm long, 1.5 cm wide at the apex, gradually widening below; the stipital bulb = 2.5-3 cm wide
DNA Sequencing Results & Discussion (originally posted on 22-May-21; updated on 3-Jul-22):
The collection was sampled for ITS by Dr. Kudzma. The raw reads showed two points of heterogeneity — one early in ITS1 and the other one in late ITS2. In both cases it’s a 1-base frame shift. In the end, two main haplotypes were recovered after the heterogeneity had been carefully resolved in both reads to achieve a consensus region of 466 bps. The major haplotype of 555 bps is 2 characters longer than the other one. Additionally, 3 isolated ambiguities were resolved (all in ITS1), thanks to the frame shift. Because the forward read has tall noise obscuring early ITS1 and the haplotypes in the reverse read were not resolved much past the point of heterogeneity in ITS1 due to the presence of triple peaks (3 haplotypes in total), the first ~40 characters of ITS1 are not reported here.
The major/longer haplotype is 98.56~99.82% similar to 12 GenBank accession, all of which but one are labeled as A. canescens/A. radiata/A. media. The shorter/minor haplotype has a 99.1-100% similarity range. The clean full-length single ITS haplotype derived from A. canescens of obs 423539 is 99.46% & 99.64% similar, respectively, to the sequences posted here.

A single basidiocarp growing on the edge of a trail in a section of the woods that is not known for fungal abundance despite the plentiful oaks nearby. This is a totally new species to me, and as far as I can tell it’s not a member of either the ‘rhodoxantus group’ or ‘leucomycelinus group’, though the basal mycelium is clearly yellow. The pictures reflect true colors, as the lighting condition were perfect.
Cap oval-shaped, somewhat pulvinate to broadly convex, 5.5 × 4.8 cm wide across the surface, with a 4.6 × 4.0 cm wide footprint, surface unpolished and subvelvety to touch, olive brown (?)/yellowish brown (5E8)/linoleum brown (5E7)/mustard brown (5E6)/bronze brown (5E5); cap flesh 9 mm thick above stipe; gills thick, decurrent, distant, straight to occasionally corrugated (wavy) and cross-veined, 5-6 mm deep, intermixing with plentiful, rounded truncate to attenuate, often wavy and shallower (less deep) lamellulae of variable length (4-5 tiers of length), dark dingy yellow (mustard yellow?) to glazed corn yellow (?), with a reddish-brown cast from spore deposits on gill blades; stipe straight in the upper 2/3, bending sharply in the lower 1/3 (= L-shaped), ~5 cm long (measured with a string), 8 mm wide in the apex, generally 7 mm wide in the upper 2/3, after the bend gradually narrowing to a pinched base terminating with a tiny bulb, surface densely squamulose-punctate in the upper 1/3, less so below, somewhat textured in the lower half and covered with sparse brownish fibrils, brownish-red in the apex and upper 1/3, color progressively paler from top to bottom, pallid in the middle with some brownish tinges and brownish-yellow in the lower 1/3; basal mycelium woolly-strigose, yellow; no surface bluing was observed on the cap surface or stipe surface or the hymenophore; cap and stipe context naturally pale to medium brownish-orange/brownish-red when cut, with the color being more vivid, darker and more brown in the stipe, apparently staining or darkening more brown over time (see photo), not bluing anywhere; odor pleasant, sweet, fungal, somewhat perfumed; taste mild but indistinct.

results.notes:
Macrolepiota procera aka Parasol mushroom.

One of the tallest mushrooms I ever saw. It was 30cm tall, and the cap width was about 8cm.

Amazing sweet smell, movable ring (which distinguishes this one from similar Amanita species), plus it had darker flakes on a lighter surface, whereas amanita species have lighter flakes (if there are any) on a darker surface such as the Panther cap.

results.notes:
A single small fruitbody – estimated to be ~7 cm tall, growing on the edge of a trail in mixed deciduous woods dominated by oak. It was growing a few yards away from the spot where the Phylloporus sp. obs 431168 had been observed just 1/2 hour prior. The cap was tacky, shiny (despite the dry weather) and brown, slightly darker on the disc than near the margin, and azonate; the margins were tuberculate-striate, the volva was tall and with pointy limbs.
Voucher preserved and sampled for sequencing in CTAB buffer.

DNA sequencing Results & Discussion (posted on 27-Feb-21):
A clean and contiguous nrDNA sequence of 613 bps almost fully supported by two reads (i.e., a consensus sequence) was obtained by Dr. Kudzma from this collection and posted to this observation. It consists of the last 46 characters of nrSSU, followed by the full-length ITS region of 480 bps and then by the first 87 bps of nrLSU. There are no ambiguities, it’s a single haplotype.
A BLASTn-100 of the full-length ITS sequence gave several accessions of Amanita sharkriverensis, a.k.a. Amanita “sp-44” as top hits at 99.60-100% similarity. Three sequenced collections of this species already exist on MO — obs 290890, obs 382744 and obs 325646 — though only the last one of these has been accessioned in GenBank.
Based on the sequencing data, Amanita sharkriverensis is known so far only from MD, NJ, WI and WV.

results.notes:
A group of 7 fruitbodies growing on the edge of a trail in mixed deciduous woods dominated in this area by oaks (with beech further out), of which 5 were collected. The basidiomata numbering is based on the cap diameter, with the largest one being #1 (see assignments in the title photo). One of the sporocarps, possibly #4, came from elsewhere in the woods (60-70 yards away), but is undoubtedly the same species and might even be the same organism. There was some superficial bluing on gill edges (see photo); a bit of bluing in the cut flesh of #1, but not in others. Ammonia applied on cap cuticle instantly bright green, slowly fading to brown.
FB#1 (“conjoined twins”): Overall height = ~5 cm; cap = 7.2 × 5.2 cm wide across top; cap flesh 1.8 cm thick above stipe; gills = 7 mm deep; stipe = 3.2 cm long, 2.5 cm wide at apex, abruptly tapering down; flesh whitish in cap, yellow at cap/stipe juncture and slightly bluing there, tinged reddish-brown in stipe.
FB #2: Overall height 6.5-7 cm; cap = 6.8 × 6.2 cm wide across top; cap flesh 2.0 cm thick above stipe; gills = 1 cm deep; stipe = 4 cm long (at the point of gill attachment), 1.2 cm wide at apex, narrowing to 6 mm in base; flesh whitish in cap, yellow above gills, tinged reddish-brown in stipe.
FB #3: Cap = 6.3 cm wide across top; cap flesh 2.8 cm thick above the point of gill attachment; gills = 9-10 mm deep; stipe = curved, 4 cm long (measured with a string), 9 mm wide at apex, narrowing to 5 mm in base.
FB #4: Overall height = 5.7 cm; cap = 5.5 × 5.0 cm wide across top; cap flesh 2.2 cm thick above the point of gill attachment; gills = 7-8 mm deep; stipe = 3.5 cm long, 7 mm wide at apex, narrowing to 5 mm in base (just above the small bulb).
FB #5: Overall height = 7 cm; cap = 4.5 × 4.2 cm wide across top; cap flesh 2.0 cm thick above the point of gill attachment; gills = 6-7 mm deep; stipe = curved, 4.7 cm long (measured with a string), 1 cm wide at apex, narrowing to 7 mm in base.
FB #6: Cap = 3.8 cm wide across top; cap flesh 1.5 cm thick above the point of gill attachment; gills = 6 mm deep; stipe = curved, 3.4 cm long (measured with a string), 7 mm wide at apex, narrowing to 4 mm in base.
DNA Sequencing Results and Discussion (posted 28-Feb-23):
This collection was sampled for ITS by Dr. Kudzma. The ITS1F-LR22 amplicon was sequenced with the same primers to produce a contiguous nrDNA sequence of 1130 bps consisting of the last 34 of nrSSU followed by a full-length ITS sequence of 766 bps and then by the first 330 bps of nrLSU. The two reads overlap in the ITS2 region for a total of 113 characters, effectively making this sequence a “joined contig” rather than a consensus sequence; the rather short overlap has to do with the read quality affecting this and many other sequences for this batch of samples.
A BLASTn-100 of the full-length ITS sequence is shown in Fig. 1. Presently, there are 19 GenBank accessions of this North American taxon mostly labeled as “Phylloporus bellus” with 98.3-99.8% similarity. Most of these are recent additions by Stephen Russell, but the oldest sequence is by Roy Halling and is associated with a 2012 reference.1 However, the present species is not P. bellus because that taxon is endemic to Asia, and later publications provide support for this hypothesis. (For a detailed discussion of this matter, see my comments in obs 415399 and obs 512692 and references cited therein.)
Fig. 2 is a phylogenetic tree from Zeng et al. (2013) shown here exclusively for illustrative purposes.2 A more modern version of this tree is in Montoya et al. 3
MO431545 is conspecific by ITS with voucher REH8710 in “Clade VI” of Zeng et al. (accession JQ003618). Zeng et al. select another taxon that authors believe to be P. leucomycelinus in “Clade V”. However, the neither type of P. leucomycelinus nor the neotype of P. rhodoxanthus proposed by Neves & Halling (2010) have been sequenced.4
References:
1 https://www2.clarku.edu/...
2 https://www.researchgate.net/...
3 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6520330/
4 https://www.researchgate.net/...

notes_fields.Macro: This collection of mushrooms was discovered by a friend on the lawn of an apartment complex in Beeville, Texas, on 01 Oct 2020. He collected samples and provided them to me. These examples are a species that I have not seen in my area before (although it could be familiar to a more experienced collector). The individual fruiting bodies seemed to grow from the top of large masses of white tissue. The stipes were impressively bulbous at the bottom, rising about 9.0 cm and supporting tan-colored, leather-like, white-gilled caps. All of the material seemed well matured. The cap cuticles were smooth with the appearance and texture of soft tan leather over a pure white flesh. The margins of the caps were incurved. The largest cap measured 11.0 cm in diameter. Stipes were solid and white inside, and no color change from bruising, application of KOH, NH4OH, or FeSo4 was noted. It appeared that the gills on my examples were not free but had mostly been torn away from the stipes by aging. There was a robust, typically-mushroom, odor present.
notes_fields.Micro: Two attempts to collect spores from gill-material smashed onto a slide failed.
notes_fields.Soil_Type: Since specimen was growing cultivated flower bed, I have not included the underlying soil type.

results.notes:
Cap with disc flushed pale tannish.
Basal volva saccate, fairly tightly fitting, with very thin limbs extending upward along the stipe.
Spores (8)9-10(12) x 7-9.
Found at the edge of oak woods during a very dry spell of weather (only recently fruited mushroom seen during this dry day). I though I could entice the fruit body to continue to expand post-harvest. I stood it up on a table with the stipe base resting on a damp napkin. But, instead of expanding it just dried out. I suspect it was already beginning to dehydrate in-situ. Much to my surprise, after it sat out for two days a spore drop developed. By this time the fruit body was not worthy of preservation. A few years back I had harvested a few of what I believed to be A. sturgeonii (Moon Lake; October). I dried them by hanging in a south-facing window for a couple days before finishing in my dryer. The material failed to yield DNA data; we believe because it dried too slowly or at too low a temperature.

results.notes:
Field notes: >8inch tall. Cap over 1in before opening then two days later: Cap 4in, stem and cap powdery scabrous, moist. Stipe with pendant annulus toward the apex, orange/ochre and white toward the base, stuffed but hollowing toward the base. Sneezing like crazy. Odor mild, like celery. No bruising/staining.

Identification: see MO observations #180613, #66374, #235010 and #280238 for comparison. There has been some discussion on MO re A. crocopeplus and A. trisulphuratus. My impression is that A. crocopeplus is larger, more orange/ochre (vs. yellow/orange), and more powdery.

This specimen is over 8 inches tall, even taller than the 4 inches described by Berkeley and Broome. Also the gills are pale, though comparing different observations on MO as well as iNaturalist it appears that the gills darken with age.

The other anomaly is that this specimen is from Guatemala whereas almost all other reports are from Asia/Africa. There is, however, one observation from iNaturalist in Rio Grande do Sul, Brazil.

Regrettably, I don’t have a dried sample. If I come across one of its descendants, I will do.

results.notes:
A single fruitbody growing at the base of an old oak. There were other large oaks nearby. A number of oak-loving porcini observations have been made in this immediate area (a circle with a 25 yard radius) over the last 9 years. For example, obs 70538, obs 104822, obs 279799 all came from a spot ~10 yards away to the NW, while obs 244398 was found some 30-40 yards away to the SE of the present collection under younger oaks (one can essentially draw a straight line through these 3 sites), and obs 105057 was growing only 15-20 yards away to the S/SE from MO244398 under a separate group of younger oaks. So, after connecting all the dots, one can draw a roughly 30-60-90 right triangle.
I suspect all these posts are not only conspecific but are the same organism. Unfortunately, of these 5 earlier collections only MO244398 was preserved. Partial LSU of MO244398 tentatively places this species in the ‘Aereus Clade’ sensu Feng et al. (2012). Frustratingly, the ITS of MO244398 was polymorphic.
